Hi Martin,

Your illustration (http://www.martinpyka.de/wp-content/upload=
s/2013/04/evolvability.png) is very helpful in teasing apart how undirected=
 genetic mutations (interpreting the isocloud on the left as the genetic sp=
ace) can yet produce structured phenotypic changes (interpreting the image =
on the right as the corresponding changes in the phenotype) through an evol=
vable genotype-phenotype map. 

Thanks for taking the effort to create the =
image, which also clarifies how canalization can work to potentially enhanc=
e evolvability. I am learning much from this discussion too.

Joel

--- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "martin_pyka" <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Joel,
>=
 
> thanks for your fast response which addressed exactly my inquiry. 
> 
>=
 First, I want to clarify that even if evolvability can reach a maximum the=
 conclusion of your paper is correct that it can emerge without any pressur=
e for adaptation in the individuals. In this regard, my question whether a =
maximum of evolvability exists was more of general nature.
> 
> > The way I=
 think about it currently is that perhaps there is no ultimate tension, and=
 that evolvability can generally increase without limit. The reason is that=
 canalization of low-level mechanisms can act to increase evolvability. For=
 example, many of the mechanisms behind development are heavily conserved, =
but can generate much phenotypic variability through being combined and mod=
ulated in various ways. In other words, modulating conserved features of de=
velopment gives evolution higher-level levers that enable small genetic cha=
nges to be amplified and have a large meaningful phenotypic effect. Thus th=
rough continued evolution of the genotype/phenotype map, perhaps evolvabili=
ty can continually increase (through exploiting canalization of lower-level=
 mechanisms to generate increasingly high-level features).
> 
> Yep, when I=
 read this I noted that this is actually also my opinion about generative e=
ncodings. From this perspective, I would also assume that evolvability can =
continuously increase in the sense that the genome can become more powerful=
 (or more flexible) in generating new meaningful phenotypes. Maybe my impli=
cit assumption was not correct that evolvability in a phenotype map could b=
e depicted as iso-oriented point-cloud:
> 
> left image in http://www.marti=
npyka.de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png
> 
> According to this=
 illustration, increased evolvability would increase the size of the point =
cloud. I think I had this picture in mind when I argued in my previous post=
 that evolvability cannot increase infinitely because genotype-phenotype ma=
ppings should become instable when a certain degree of evolvability has bee=
n reached. However, maybe a 2d-depiction of the evolvable phenotype-space w=
ould rather look like in the right image (I am sorry for my poor artwork). =
Through canalization, not all phenotypes in the 2d-space are evolvable but =
evolvability itself can still increase!?
> 
> Maybe, both pictures can also=
 illustrate what canalization means. The left picture could depict all poss=
ible points in the genotype space that can be reached through mutation and =
recombination and the right image all possible points in the phenotype spac=
e that can be generated from it. While each bit in the (2d)-genotype has eq=
ual probability of been mutated, in canalized encodings only a well-ordered=
 subspace of phenotypes can be reached.
> 
> Thank you for this inspiring d=
iscussion. :-) I enjoy thinking about how all this fits together.
> 
> Best=
,
> Martin
>
